bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, November 23, 1874

div1.p: Reed is worried that he may be writing Emilie Lawrence too frequently. He is sick but will persevere to take his medical exam.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, November 23, 1874
div1.p:
It is the
hour of morning, but such
a morning! The sun has
hid his face, as if to in-
dicate his unwillingness
to longer shine on an
ungrateful world: a heavy
fog hangs, like a pall, over
the “City of Churches”; the
winds sigh mournfully, as
they pass, bearing on their
bosom the sighs and pe-
titions of earth's poor, friend-
less creatures, and repeat-
ing the oft-told story of
“Man's inhumanity to Man”;
the rain-drops descending
thick and fast from the
dark, overhanging clouds
complete the scene; a
scene as uninviting as
it well could be.
Who, at such a time, would
neglect to thank his Maker
for the provision of a com-
fortable home against the
“contending elements,” or
would fail to breath a
silent prayer that He,
who “tempers the winds to
the shorn lambs,” would
also protect the houseless,
homeless wanderer.

Several causes
have contributed to my
delay in writing.
First, this thought
occurred to me -- In
writing so often, am
I not laying too great
a burden on you? Or, in other
words, am I not converting
into labor what should
otherwise serve as a source
of recreation? I am certain
that the same thought has
occurred to you more
than once. Now to speak
plainly, I would not have
the correspondence become
irksome to you for the
whole world and all that
therin is. I hope you under-
stand me, for I would not
have you misconstrue my
meaning. Pray don't think
that I have drawn such
a conclusion from anything
contained in your letters,
for such is not the case.
My only reason for alluding
to the subject w is due to
my anxiety lest I may be
taxing your time too much
by writing so frequently.
I know that it must con-
sume much valuable time, &
now that you have a former
school-mate with whom you
can pass so many pleas-
ant hours, your time will
be doubly valuable. This
solution of the problem has
occurred to me. Permit me
to answer your letters as
promptly as I choose, and
in return, reply when it
is most suitable to you,
and in no way allow your
other pursuits to be inter-
fered with. I anticipate
the arrival of your letters
with much pleasure, but I
would not have you con-
clude from this that the
longer the anticipation, the
greater the pleasure, &
hence not write at all.
Anticipation long continued
brings suspense and
suspense is, of all
things, the least to
be endured -- “Hope deferred
maketh the heart sick.”
You cannot now fail to
fully comprehend my
words. And yet, I regret
that I have mentioned the
subject. I am afraid you
will begin to think that I
am tiring of the correspon-
dence. By thus thinking, you
could not do me greater injury.
By all that is good and true,
such are not my feelings,
nor would I do aught to
interrupt what has been
to me so extremely agree-
able. But I know, Miss
Lawrence, that human na-
ture is so peculiar, and that
we are so apt to magnify
mole-hills into mountains.
In fact were it anyone else
than yourself, I should tear
up this letter and begin
anew. As it is, I have such
confidence in your good
sense that I am well-pur-
suaded that you will attribute
my words soely solely to a desire
to prevent the correspondence
from becoming burdensome
to you. If you do not approve
of my propositions, by all
means, say so, and I will
lend a ready ear to any
suggestions you have to
make, even though you
should tell me “to mind my
own business.” I would be
only too to happy to hear
that you do not con-
sider my letters too
frequently written.
My second excuse is but the
repetition of the same, old
story -- ill-health -- Alas! I am
so harrassed! What to do
surpasses the “infinite of
thought.” At no time of my
life did I ever appreciate
more forcibly the statement
that, “time and tide wait
for no man-” I must study --
not a moment to lose -- and
it is this same studying
that has all along delayed
my convalescence. Sick!
Why I haven't drawn an
unsound breath for years!
but now, when I need all
my strength, lo! it fails
me! Is it not enough to
disturb the smooth current
of one's thoughts? It is like
attempting to climb a hill
with too great a burden.
But what am I do? Health
or no health I must stand
my examination in January.
Language would fail to
describe my chagrin and
mortification, were I to be
prevented from so doing
by reason of sickness.
Somebody would call me
fickle, and accuse me of
not carrying out my pur-
poses, and this I am de-
termined shall not be
said- I have been fickle
years ago, but I have put
aside childish things, and,
at present, I do not aban-
don my plans, unless some
good reason offers. Of
course, I would not persist
in doing one thing when
I found that by abandoning
it, I might gain a better.
Still, I believe that when
a person determines
to accomplish an end,
that he should put
forth all honest effort, nor
turn aside unless for the
best of reasons; and if
he meets with defeat, let
him accept it like a man,
remembering that many a
better men have found
themselves in a like sit-
uation. At all events, I shall
pursue my course till
every prop is knocked from
under me -- “Sufficient unto
the day is the evil therof.”

And now to repent
of my misdoings, if such
they can be called.
Miss Emilie (patience! what
have I said? Your name es-
caped me before I was
aware of it- I don't like to begin
another sheet & write it all over
again -- it is such a labor -- besides
will you not permit me to
be less formal and call you
Miss Emilie?) I was going to
say, I am ever so sorry if
my reference to you in my
last letter occassioned you
sadness. I need a lecture,
I know, for speaking so
boldly- You remember that
the poet has said; “it is
the heart and not the brain
that unto the highest doth
attend attain;” and I sup-
pose he might have sub-
stituted “boldest” for “highest”
with equal truth and propriety.
I am sure you
consider me extremely
rude -- in fact, I
feel just like a bear!
But you know I never should
have paid you such com-
pliments, had I not firmly
believed every word I uttered.
Compliments! why I did not
look upon them as such!
Cans't thou add aught to
the rainbow's hues? But
stop! or I will again give
occassion for displeasure.
Your modesty I truly appre-
ciate, and I can imagine in
a small degree with what
indignation you received my
remarks. I have been more
than once complimented, but
always by my own relations-
My brother Kit was accus-
tomed to speak of me flat-
teringly to various young-
ladies, and I always retal-
iated by persistently refus-
ing to become acquainted
with these ladies, well-knowing
that I should appear as a
perfect ignoramus. However,
this question, like most others,
has two sides and quite dif-
ferent ones- If, by compli-
menting, you convey a wrong
impression of a person's
abilities, it is surely doing
an injustice; but if you
state facts that are plainly
visible to anyone, that is
quite another matter- The
latter part of the foregoing
sentence would aptly apply
to yourself, while the first
part might be justly
hurled at the witless head
of your unworthy servant.
You were right in not at-
tributing to me the title of
“flatterer.” No, Miss Emilie,
I am do not flatter any
one.

Flattery is as much to be
deprecated as to speak
disparagingly of one.
I always endeavour
to avoid either extreme. I
never expect to find perfection
in any one's character -- that
is impossible -- all have
faults -- all, imperfections --
Still, in this day of rapid
progress, when young ladies
(and gentlemen too) are wont
to give more attention to
outward appearances than
to inward culture; when it is
so rare to find one who
combines culture of the mind
with those other, lesser ac-
complishments (which though
not so important, are yet
considered necessary) it is
but natural that we should
pay our respects and admi-
ration to such sterling worth
as oft as we meet with it.
Since, however, you desire me
to avoid alluding to you in such
strains, I must submit, though
not cheerfully- You can quiet
my pen but not my brain.

So the doctor's happi-
ness is complete? I congrat-
ulate him wilth with all my heart
and wish him all possible
joy and success in life. I
know of no man who should
be more contented. Sur-
rounded by loving friends,
living in a “goodly land,”
amongst a pleasant people,
supplied with a sufficiency
of this world's goods, in the
beginning of manhood when
life is so full of
hope, an honored
member of the noblest
profession on this round
globe, and, added to all
these things, blessed with
a sweet, young wife! What
more could mortal ask?
for? When I look on so
bright a picture and then
turn my thoughts to the future
and consider my bachelor-
days, I feel a little out of
humor, to say the least-
How dark the horizon!
not a ray to cheer me on;
no hand that extended that
I may grasp in mine and
feel a new interest in life;
no “eye to mark my coming
and look brighter when I
come;” no smile to greet me
when the day's work is done;
no gentle voice to give
encouragement amid life's
sore trials! Such, such is
mine!! “So mote it be,” since
thus it must be. There is noth-
ing like philosophically accep-
ting the inevitable.
Others have trod the lonely road,
And why not I as well;
Others have sunk beneath the load,
I'll fall where others fell!
If I cannot obtain the
prize I seek, this should not
cause me to wish my friends
the same misfortune- In fact,
it is the bachelor's peculiar
duty and privelege to look,
with an approving eye, on
all his married friends, and to
wish them long life and hap-
piness -- a kind of general
adviser, though not “master
of the situation.” There were
many other things I had intended
speakings of, but want of space forbids,
div1.closer:
I remain,
very truly, your friend, Walter Reed.
